content.text: Estimate the volume of water \(V_{\mathrm{W}}\) that the beaker would hold when filled to the top
The student uses string and a metre rule to determine the circumference \(c\) of the beaker
Explain briefly how to use the string and the metre rule to determine the circumference \(c\) as accurately as possible. You may draw a diagram
Show clearly on Fig. 1.1, the height \(h\) that he should measure
His reading is \(h =\) 9.0 cm
Calculate the external volume \(V_{\mathrm{B}}\) of the beaker using the equation
The student measures the height \(h\) of the beaker
Write down the mass \(m_{\mathrm{B}}\) of the beaker, to the nearest gram
The student fills the beaker to the top with dry sand. He measures the mass \(m\) of the beaker containing the sand

parts.label: (ii)

content.text: Calculate the mass \(m_{\mathrm{S}}\) of sand in the beaker. Use the equation \(m_{\mathrm{S}} = (m - m_{\mathrm{B}})\)

content.text: Calculate the density \(\rho\) of the sand using the equation
Include the unit
The student measures the mass of the beaker on a balance, as shown in Fig. 1.2

The student uses a measuring cylinder to measure the volume of dry sand. Draw a diagram of the measuring cylinder and show the line of sight that the student must use to obtain an accurate volume reading
A student determines the density of sand
Fig. 1.1 shows a beaker with a mark at the \(250 \text{cm}^3\) level

• The line \(\mathbf{MR}\) shows the position of a plane mirror. Draw a normal to this line that passes through its centre. Continue the normal so that it reaches the bottom of the ray-trace sheet. Label the normal \(\mathbf{NL}\). Label the point at which \(\mathbf{NL}\) crosses \(\mathbf{MR}\) with the letter \(\mathbf{B}\)
• Draw a line \(\mathbf{CD}\) 5.0 cm below \(\mathbf{MR}\) and parallel to \(\mathbf{MR}\)
• Label the point \(\mathbf{X}\) where \(\mathbf{CD}\) crosses \(\mathbf{NL}\)
• Draw a line \(\mathbf{EF}\) 5.0 cm below \(\mathbf{CD}\) and parallel to \(\mathbf{CD}\)
• Label the point \(\mathbf{Y}\) where \(\mathbf{EF}\) crosses \(\mathbf{NL}\)

Draw a line 7.0 cm long from \(\mathbf{B}\) at an angle of incidence \(\theta_{1} = 20^{\circ}\) to the normal below \(\mathbf{MR}\) and to the left of the normal. Label the end of this line \(\mathbf{A}\)
The student places two pins, \(\mathsf{P}_1\) and \(\mathsf{P}_2\) , on line \(\mathbf{AB}\) . Suggest a suitable distance \(x\) between the pins for this type of ray-trace experiment
Measure and record the distance \(a\) from \(\mathbf{X}\) to \(\mathsf{P}_3\)
Measure and record the distance \(b\) from \(\mathbf{Y}\) to \(\mathsf{P}_4\)
Calculate \(\frac{a}{b}\)

The student views the images of pins \(\mathsf{P}_1\) and \(\mathsf{P}_2\) from the direction indicated by the eye in Fig. 2.1. She places pin \(\mathsf{P}_3\) on line \(\mathbf{CD}\) so that the images of \(\mathsf{P}_2\) and \(\mathsf{P}_1\) appear exactly behind pin \(\mathsf{P}_3\)

She places pin \(\mathsf{P}_4\) on line \(\mathbf{EF}\) so that pin \(\mathsf{P}_3\) , and the images of \(\mathsf{P}_2\) and \(\mathsf{P}_1\) , all appear exactly behind pin \(\mathsf{P}_4\) . The positions of \(\mathsf{P}_3\) and \(\mathsf{P}_4\) are shown on Fig. 2.1
The student repeats the procedure using an angle of incidence \(\theta_{2} = 40^{\circ}\). She records the new values of \(a\) and \(b\)
Calculate the new value \(\frac{a}{b}\)
State and explain whether the two values of \(\frac{a}{b}\) can be considered to be equal in this experiment
A student carries out this experiment with care. Suggest a practical reason why the results may not be accurate
A student investigates the position of the image in a plane mirror
Fig. 2.1 shows the ray-trace sheet that the student uses

content.text: Calculate the resistance \(R_{1}\) of the resistor using the equation \(R_{1} = \frac{V_{1}}{I_{1}}.\)
The student measures the current \(I\) in the circuit
He places the sliding contact S at C and measures the potential difference (p.d.) \(V_{1}\) across the resistor R
The voltmeter and ammeter are shown in Fig. 3.2 and Fig. 3.3
Fig. 3.2
Fig. 3.3
The student disconnects the voltmeter from terminal B and connects the voltmeter to terminal C
He places the sliding contact S at a distance \(l = 20.0 \text{cm}\) from C. He records, in Table 3.1, the reading on the voltmeter
He repeats the procedure using \(l = 40.0 \text{cm}\), \(60.0 \text{cm}\), \(80.0 \text{cm}\) and \(100.0 \text{cm}\). His readings are shown in Table 3.1
Plot a graph of \(V/V\) (y-axis) against \(l/\mathrm{cm}\) (x-axis). Start both axes at the origin (0,0)

Use your value of \(V_{1}\) from (a)(i) to find the length \(l_{\mathrm{R}}\) of resistance wire that has the same resistance as resistor R. Show clearly on the graph how you obtained the necessary information
The resistance of the resistance wire is proportional to its length. Estimate the resistance of \(100 \text{cm}\) of the resistance wire
estimate .........
A student investigates resistance

A student investigates springs made from different metals
Plan an experiment to investigate the extension of springs made from different metals
The following apparatus is available:
boss, clamp and stand
metre rule
springs made from different metals
selection of loads with hangers
You can also use other apparatus and materials that are usually available in a school laboratory
In your plan, you should:
• write a list of suitable metals for the springs
• draw a diagram of the set up you would use
• explain briefly how to carry out the investigation
• state the key variables to keep constant
• draw a table, or tables, with column headings, to show how to display your readings (you are **not** required to enter any readings in the table)
• explain how you would use the readings to reach a conclusion
